Author: meatwad2567#8623
Content: does anyone know how to expand the "radius" of a sprite, specifically for a sensing function?

Author: meatwad2567#8623
Content: I'm trying to make something with the bigger sprites, but each sprite still just seems to have a single point on the grid where another object can be "touching"

Author: meatwad2567#8623
Content: so the touching function won't work in a lot of instances where visually it looks like it should

Author: Aternus#9711
Content: The pixels of your sprite should be fully "on" i.e. black or white in order to make the sensing consistent

Author: Aternus#9711
Content: Thus if you want to have precise sensing, you need to create two sprites, the graphical one (with full color and transparency) and the other one that has the same shape but fully black or white (black is preferred for debugging purposes)

Author: Aternus#9711
Content: Then you need to sync both sprites using events, and attach an event for the black sprite

Author: Aternus#9711

Author: Joshua#4339
Content: what is the good way roadmap of learning programming

Author: Wilco#4718
Content:
@Joshua There isn't really a "perfect" way of learning anything in this world‚Äîespecially something as diverse as programming. I'd start by looking up blogs written by those who have already started/finished the journey of learning programming to their desired standard and find out how they did and what you can take away from their experience.

Medium (https://medium.com/) is a great place for stories and blogs such as I mentioned above and I gave this a read this morning which may prove useful to you too: https://medium.freecodecamp.org/graphic-designer-to-front-end-developer-7be7bfd6a46c _(Incidentally, that blog-post is why I'm here, enrolled in CS50, today)_.

Content: hi people!  am embarking on my first foray into scratch.  i have a bunch of actions that i only want to start happening once the space bar is pressed.  is there a way to start a timer when the space bar is pressed?  so that i can then have other things start happening x seconds after the space bar is pressed/the bulk of my actions start unfolding?  basically  i want a set of timed actions to happen in sequence/at various points in time, but only after the space bar is pressed.

Content: @ferazel9 might help? https://en.scratch-wiki.info/wiki/Timer_(value)

Content: hmmm thanks...i'll play around with this and see if i can get somewhere üòÉ

Content: @curiouskiwi thanks again for your help!  i figured it out and realized i didn't actually need to use the Timer; instead, since i wanted a countdown to basically start once the space key was pressed (triggering other things) i just used the "when space key is pressed-->wait x seconds" thing and all is now well!  thanks again :]

Author: corwin562#8543
Content: can someone explain the variable for me

Author: Deadly#8966
Content: @corwin562 What is it you do not understand about them? You use variables to store a value. Create a variable, give it a name, and then it will ask for a scope (what can access it, all scripts or just this script). Once you create the variable you get more blocks that allow you to set the value, increment the value, and or show or hide the value in the window.  For example, you can create a "Score" variable, and anytime something good happens in your game you change the Score by 1 or whatever value.  You can use it as a switch too, like a light bulb, set 0 in the variable for off, and 1 for on, and you can use IF blocks to check if the variable is 0 or 1 to decide what to do.

Author: corwin562#8543
Content: @Deadly thank you.

If nothing else, I am going to work through some of the guided game builds in this book: https://www.amazon.com/Coding-Games-Scratch-Jon-Woodcock/dp/1465439358/ and see if inspiration strikes, but I thought I would ask anyone here: have you run into a Scratch tutorial or guide that helped inspire you to make a creative game? Would anyone like to share an idea on choice of genre or game mechanics that worked well for them?

Author: SCWacko#4456
Content: You could focus on making a comedy based game. For example, have an rpg like game where certain paths taken lead to a funny event or compete against a computer that gets angry if you win. For example, I made a memory game where there's a squirrel that gets mad at you and leaves after 10 successful button push sequences. https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/220748311/ There are also story based games where it's less about the gameplay and more about the story that's being told http://www.addictinggames.com/zombie-games/i-saw-her-standing-there-game.jsp

Author: S4nie#4759
Content:
Your project must have at least two sprites, at least one of which must resemble something other than a cat.

Your project must have at least three scripts total (i.e., not necessarily three per sprite).

Your project must use at least one condition, one loop, and one variable.

Your project must use at least one sound.

Your project should be more complex than most of those demonstrated in lecture (many of which, though instructive, were quite short) but it can be less complex than Oscartime. As such, your project should probably use a few dozen puzzle pieces overall.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: You would get a transcript from Harvard at the end of the course.  But if you are starting university this fall, full time, where you are, you might find the workload to be a bit much to do CS50 at the same time, with its weekly time pressures.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: I don't think taking CS50 on its own is going to help with a Masters degree application.  Surely they'd care more about your undergraduate degree and all its courses..  CS50 is only 1 of the 32 courses that are required for a Harvard bachelors degree.

Author: Deleted User#0000
Content: I'm thinking about how you could implement the horizontal scrolling in Scratch... I'm guessing an incrementing integer that goes up when you press the right-arrow key. Then every "sprite"/object on the screen shifts position left on the x-axis on that same arrow-key event. Then use the Looks->Hide command on sprites when they reach an invisible boundary wall at the left of the screen... to spawn new sprites at certain points you could add an if control like "if game_frame > 150 then show" on an enemy object/sprite.

Author: MemeSensei#6096

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
Your project must have at least two sprites, at least one of which must resemble something other than a cat.

Your project must have at least three scripts total (i.e., not necessarily three per sprite).

Your project must use at least one condition, one loop, and one variable.

Your project must use at least one sound.

Your project should be more complex than most of those demonstrated in lecture (many of which, though instructive, were quite short) but it can be less complex than Oscartime. As such, your project should probably use a few dozen puzzle pieces overall.

Author: yeshhh#7329
Content: Hello I‚Äôm doing the problem set 0 and there‚Äôs a bug in my scratch that I don‚Äôt know how to fix it

Author: yeshhh#7329
Content: There‚Äôs a cat gliding left to right and I want it to stop gliding when the space key is pressed

Author: yeshhh#7329
Content: I even put the control repeat until key space is pressed

Author: yeshhh#7329
Content: But it doesn‚Äôt seem to work

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: @yeshhh so you are using the glide block?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: this one? https://en.scratch-wiki.info/wiki/Glide_()_Secs_to_X:_()_Y:_()_(block)

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: or the move block?

Author: yeshhh#7329
Content: Glide block

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so the glide block will go for however many seconds you put, and all other scripts are delayed until that block finishes.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: maybe you want a simple move block

Author: yeshhh#7329
Content: I just put one second

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: but it won't listen for the key press until it finishes the glide, so if it's in a forever loop, it won't stop

Author: yeshhh#7329
Content: It‚Äôs  pointing upward like it‚Äôs supposed to but it wouldn‚Äôt stop gliding

Author: VelocityIsntSpeed#9490
Content: No human checks the scratch game we make in pset0, right? They mention complexity requirements but i don't recall the automated grading even checking the amount of blocks that i used

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: the check50 script checks the specified requirements.  at least: one sound, one variable, one loop, one conditions, three scripts, two sprites (one of which is not a cat).    Meeting all of those conditions means that your program meets the requirements.

Author: VelocityIsntSpeed#9490
Content: You're missing a bullet point from the pset0 page: `Your project should be more complex than most of those demonstrated in lecture (many of which, though instructive, were quite short) but it can be less complex than Oscartime. As such, your project should probably use a few dozen puzzle pieces overall.` https://docs.cs50.net/2018/x/psets/0/pset0.html

Author: VelocityIsntSpeed#9490
Content: @curiouskiwi Check50 dosn't check that, apparently

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: no, it doesn't because if you have all the other requirements, it's a good bet that you have enough puzzle pieces

Author: Nornor#4436
Content: hey everyone, should i implement one of my past programming projects in scratch or come up with a new one. ( by past programming projects i mean projects that I've already done in another programming language )

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: @Nornor it's up to you.  The Scratch pset is meant to gently introduce you to the concepts of programming, like loops, variables, etc.   If you're already experienced, take it as an opportunity to create something fun.  (just be sure you include all the required elements per the spec)

- if answer incorrect, say incorrect/repeat question until correct

Content: Try using a variable that gets set to `1` when the answer is correct

Content: Hey @Princess Sugar great job! I thought it was pretty fun to play. It being mouse movement was kind of fun and I thought the lore was pretty creative. Author: Princess Sugar#1234

Author: Infi#2773
Content: Yeah, it's honestly cool jumping into the water for the first time. Don't be afraid to ask the discord for help or tips, everyone here seems to be really nice. Also, one small last suggestion. If you made all your sprites a bit smaller, it could give the user the illusion of having more space to move around. Anyways, great first time project.

Author: Princess Sugar#1234
Content: Ok I tweaked the sprites sizes some and varied them a little to add more diversity as well. I also made earning life hearts a bit more random and rare to add to the challenge. üòÑ

Author: Arthanian#1822
Content:
Hello!  I have a question when working with C.  During the video we are thought to use ‚Äú ‚Äú in between parenthesis.  However, when it is used  with if, while or for,  we are not using them.  Why is that? 

Example:
If (x<y) 
While (true)

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: in what video?

Author: Arthanian#1822
Content: CS50 intro to CS week 1.

Author: Arthanian#1822
Content: Would a script crash if quotations are added inside a condition?  Or why are there no quotation marks inside parentheses?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: are you talking about something like `printf("hello, world\n")`  where the argument to the function called `printf` is a string (where all strings are surrounded with double quotes)?

Author: Arthanian#1822
Content: The condition.  Before the function.

Author: Arthanian#1822
Content:
Example: 
If (true)

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: if you said `if ("x<y")` that would simply not work at all as you'd expect

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: because `"x<y"` would be a string

Author: Arthanian#1822
Content: Conditions will never have strings?

Author: Arthanian#1822
Content: Sorry for the questions it was throwing me off when following up the video

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: I think David was giving the printf example and said "you have to surround it with double quotes in C" ... he was referring to the words "hello, world"  not all things in parentheses.   https://video.cs50.net/2018/fall/lectures/1?t=19m14s

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: he explains that about here:  https://video.cs50.net/2018/fall/lectures/1?t=41m59s

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: you can search the transcript for "double quotes" to see all the places they are mentioned in the video if you need to review.

Author: Arthanian#1822
Content:
Thank you very much for the help.
What would u say its a variable?  Its the only thing in my notes that I dont know how to describe it or define it.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: again, I'd search for `variable` in the video player transcript.  You can review it that way.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: those are all clickable to take you to that part of the video (

Author: Pie Burritos#6623
Content:
If you want the screen to change you could make a trigger so that if your character reaches a certain x or y position, the background will change and all entities will vanish and get replaced by new entities, and the position of your character will also change to match the new area. Basically just create a "when I receive" for everything you want to change and hide everything you don't want anymore and add everything you do want in order to generate the new stage.
It's seems like a lot of work and there might be a better way to go about this, but that's all I can think of.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: @Berky_Ross Do you get all green smileys? Not all the tests have a message below. Some just are title and smiley.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: `check50` should be pretty fast. Nobody wants to throw massive compute resources on a check.

Author: Berky_Ross#6951
Content: Ok sec I will check it

Author: Berky_Ross#6951
Content: Yep all green smileys

Author: Berky_Ross#6951
Content: I saw "checking that project.."

Content: Thought it's still in process.

Author: Berky_Ross#6951
Content: Thanks for help this rly annoyed me @Blauelf

Author: Berky_Ross#6951
Content: I thought it's my connection.

Author: Berky_Ross#6951
Content: Would I get a reply or something on this submission?

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
The individual checks only write something below if they have something to say. It's more meant to understand what's going on if a check fails. Could help finding bugs in the checker (things do break sometimes mostly due to updates), or point you to the problem with your code.
You will find your scores on cs50.me, in the "courses" section.

Author: Berky_Ross#6951
Content: So there is real ppl who rly.check the thing?

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Only in the later courses (games, web, mobile), where automated checks would be harder to do.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: CS50x is almost fully automated (I think the transfer of finisher list to EDX for certificates in case people paid is manual). Your commit to the repo triggered a bunch of tests, and those would appear on the course's scores list.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Oh, the `check50` button (which just links to an existing report, does not trigger checks again) is in the submissions, not scores. But - you get the idea.

Author: Berky_Ross#6951
Content: oh

Author: Berky_Ross#6951
Content: so that's the check, they just make sure I met all the requirements , right? @Blauelf

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: The ones they can test automatically. The checker will likely unzip the submission, parse the source for the elements it expects. It will probably not actually execute the code.

Author: silence#7352
Content:
I have a bit of a complex problem with my triggers in scratch, perhaps someone can assist me...
I have three sprites which when touched in a particular order give a unique arrangement of other sprites on screen. But each order of touches gives a different arrangement and I need to try to stop the touch orders from interrupting one another, which so far have caused some serious bugs in the arrangement of the screen. 
I'm really not explaining this very well but I don't know how else to describe the problem

Author: silence#7352
Content: If there is a script that is waiting for an event: is there a way to interrupt that waiting with another script with another outcome?

Author: kadavraverkisto#7943
Content: Starting it with a check for a flag variable set by the other script?

Author: silence#7352
Content: Hm I don't think so because they'd both be waiting simultaneously to be touched and the player of course has to choose one and by extent cancel the other's wait

Author: silence#7352
Content: I think I've found a way around the problem though. I have a variable which dictates a value for each layout, and an if function instead of a wait function on the triggers

Author: silence#7352
Content:
Basically:
Forever
   if layout == x
     If player touches, set layout to a
   Else hide

Author: kadavraverkisto#7943
Content: Hm, isn't it too early for hide?

Author: kadavraverkisto#7943
Content: I mean, it will just disappear in the first cycle.

Author: silence#7352
Content: No no, it's hiding but still always checking for layout==x so next time it ticks to x the trigger will appear again

Author: kadavraverkisto#7943
Content:
maybe something like
while layout==x
    if touched set layout to a
hide

Author: silence#7352
Content: I haven't figured out while functions in scratch yet üòÖ

Content: I don't remember them too well myself... And I can't check them in the moment, because my internet connection dies on me xD

Author: silence#7352
Content: I've got scratch open in front of me, I don't see any while blocks ü§î

Author: silence#7352
Content: Either way, I've tested my way and it works flawlessly now so I'm happy

Author: silence#7352

Author: Lily~#0001
Content: So how do I make it choose a different costume randomly? üòÖ @Hyuri

Author: Hyuri#2052
Content: You can use the "set costume [ ]" and put a "pick random ( ) ( )" in it

Author: Hyuri#2052
Content: Then set the "pick random" to between the number of costumes you have

Author: Hyuri#2052
Content: If you're creating clones, you need to put all of this under the "when I start as a clone" event block

Author: Lily~#0001
Content: Would it be easier with clones or not... I wonder

Author: Hyuri#2052
Content: Depends on whether you want to spawn just one, or many

Author: Lily~#0001
Content: Well lets start with just one @Hyuri

Author: Lily~#0001
Content: When I set it to create a clone of myself, what will that do exactly? üòÖ

Author: Hyuri#2052
Content: Spawn a clone of the sprite üòõ

Author: Hyuri#2052
Content: The same costume and blocks will be cloned

Author: Lily~#0001
Content: But it wont be like a seperate sprite?

Author: Hyuri#2052
Content: Yep

Author: Hyuri#2052
Content: You can create many clones and they'll all have the same properties as the originator

Author: Hyuri#2052
Content: But you can add a block to the original one that says "when I start as a clone", and then the blocks below that will only execute if the sprite is a clone, and not the original

Author: Hyuri#2052
Content: You can do some cool things with it, like spawning copies of buffs, or copies of bullets for example

Author: detan386#6610
Content: Is there any deadline for the problem set 0 for edx students?

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
Not a real one. In January, the CS50x course content is replaced with new one based on then last fall's CS50 course. Any new submissions then have to be according to the new problem descriptions, which usually don't differ that much from the old ones (maybe a few problems get replaced). So it might be best to not work on something large during the time of that switch.
But the course is renamed to the new year, all the scores are migrated, mapped to the most appropriate new problem. No need to enroll again or something.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: @FunkMonster do you see any errors in your Chrome developer tool console?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
there's an alternate way to upload it.  Can you try this?  
* Go to `https://github.com/me50/USERNAME`, replacing `USERNAME` in the URL with your own GitHub username.    
* On the left side of the screen, click on **Branch: master**.    
* In the field that says **Find or create a branch...**, copy and paste precisely this value, `cs50/problems/2019/x/scratch`, then click **Create branch**. 
* Click the button that says **Upload files**.    
* Drag your `.sb3` file into the box that says **Drag files here**.    
* Click the green **Commit changes** button.

Author: Quasar#4040
Content: Question, how high is the bar for a 70% grade?

Author: Quasar#4040
Content: Whats the difference between a 70% project and a 100% project?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
it's autograded to meet all the requirements in the spec, so your grade is based on (number of requirements met)/number of requirements.  For example, here's the grade sheet for an 88% project:  

üôÇ project exists and is valid Scratch program
üò¶ project contains at least two sprites
only 1 sprite found, 2 required 
üôÇ project contains a non-cat sprite
üôÇ project contains at least three blocks
üôÇ project uses at least one condition
üôÇ project uses at least one loop
üôÇ project uses at least one variable
üôÇ project uses at least one sound

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: 7 out of 8 = 88%

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: @Quasar ^^

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so to pass, you need at least 6 out of 8

Author: Quasar#4040
Content: Thanks! Is there a place we can find the requirements in the future so I don't have to ask you every time?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: Well, the requirements are spelled out in the spec.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: But in later weeks (starting week 3) you'll be able to run the grading script yourself before you submit.  but for now, once you submit, you can see the tests run.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Yes.

Author: Kinƒça#1067
Content: It can be done in minutes

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: A minimal project for just checking off all the hard requirements, yes.

Author: Kasey#0580
Content: Hey everyone. I just started Lecture 0/Week 0 a few days ago. I'm reading over Problem Set 0 and need to clarify- we are supposed to fulfill all those requirements for Problem Set 0 (implement a complex Scratch project) within a week? I haven't dove into it yet, but it seems really daunting. I guess I'm just wondering how long project 0 took for everyone else?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: I know for the Harvard students, the average was 5 hours.

Author: Kasey#0580
Content: Are people actually starting from scratch (no pun intended)? Or just pulling up an .sb3 file similar to the project they want to do, and pulling elements off of that?

Author: Kasey#0580
Content: *.sb3 file from the zip files in Lecture 0

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: starting from scratch I'd imagine

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: I know when I did CS50x, my very simple (but meeting all the requirements) scratch problem took me about 4 hours?  But as I said, it was very simple.

Author: Kasey#0580
Content: Thanks so much for answering. I've been looking through some other people's scratch projects and they look SO complicated. I'm sure it has to do with experimenting and trial/error, so I guess I just need to try üôÇ

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: some people spend a long time on them. üôÇ   It depends on if you really want to do something big/complicated, or just enough to understand the concepts and then move on.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: also, of course, the Harvard students have strict weekly deadlines, so they don't have time to spend days on it.

Author: Kasey#0580
Content: Haha, definitely. I'd think most people here probably have full time jobs.

Author: Kasey#0580
Content: Sorry last question (hopefully)- used the Discord search function. Is it right that there's technically no due date for the problem sets? I'd guess it's better to turn it in sooner rather than later, because then projects would just start piling up.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: There's no final date, but the 2019 course ends on 31 Dec and the 2020 course takes its place on 1 Jan.  At that point, you need to complete the course using the 2020 problem sets (your progress from 2019 will be counted toward the 2020 course) , so you're better to submit your work as you complete it.  (Plus, the problem sets are considered a major part of the teaching material, so moving on without completing them isn't the best approach to the course).

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: Here's an idea of how much time the Harvard students took for each problem: https://cs50.harvard.edu/college/faqs/#how-much-work-is-cs50

Author: Drdaverespect#1985
Content: Hi, so i'm trying to get this to loop properly but cant seem to get it to work. the cat always stops back at the beginning of the page instead of continuing.  Any help would be appreciated. Thanks. https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/350512067

Author: Anya L#2162
Content: @Drdaverespect It stops only under the bat for me: goes to x=80, y=-125, waits for the Space bar click, then moves on to the next backdrop, where it stops at the same spot. If I understood correctly, you want it to move without stopping through 10 backdrops? You might want to fiddle with what you want inside the loop (always happens) and what you want outside (happens only once in the beginning) if that's the case. Similarly, your loop-stopping variable (Distance) has to be where the loop can check if it's 10 already. Hope it helps!

Author: Drdaverespect#1985
Content: @Anya L  I messed around with it and finally fixed my problem. Thanks though.

Author: Anya L#2162
Content: @Drdaverespect No worries :)

Author: Critter#9923
Content: Hi everyone, I am in need of assistance. I am having trouble with my enemies not sensing contact with my player and ending the game. Could anyone tell me what I am doing wrong?  The current script I am testing out is in "Beetle". https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/356780278/

Author: M0RGANZ#1496
Content: @Critter The link is empty

Author: Critter#9923
Content: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/356780278

Author: Critter#9923
Content: @M0RGANZ Fixed

Author: M0RGANZ#1496
Content: The if statement is outside the forever loop. This means it only checks once. If you put this statement within the forever loop it will check every frame.

Author: M0RGANZ#1496
Content: @Critter

Author: Critter#9923
Content: @M0RGANZ Oh that makes so much sense.  Thank you!

Author: M0RGANZ#1496
Content: @Critter @ me if you need any future help üôÇ

Content: with anything, not just scratch

Try to begin your video by saying ‚Äúhello, world‚Äù and end it with "my name is ‚Ä¶., and this is CS50." But, ultimately, it‚Äôs totally up to you.

Author: M0RGANZ#1496
Content: This could be because the size change evidently makes the condition true. And because scratch uses positioning from the center of an asset. If the circle is -500, 0 at any size it will still touch the boundary and then it will flicker because it will try to change size to make it fit. If you use the random between block instead of GO TO random, you can set it so it will never get too close

Author: M0RGANZ#1496
Content: If you want the max size to be 40

Author: CamelRider#1006
Content:
I don't recommend skipping it ,i was gonna but then i took a deep dive, as childish as it looks it is quite useful like @MY EYES  "the logic you use in it is largely the same for almost any other language" 
 you learn how to get user input and use it and how to use variables and conditions and loops 
it doesn't matter if your project gives eye cancer like mine does, it just have to be written correctly

Author: Anne Harrison#8994
Content: Hi folks, I'm feeling really stupid and really old right now. I have ideas of what I want to do, I pretty much know how to code them, the bit I'm stuck on is creating the sprites and backgrounds as I don't want to use the ones in the library. They aren't complicated to draw, but more complex that I want to grind through on the built in drawing program. I've googled around and I can't find the required image format (I did see one place say bmp, but in playing around it's let me upload a jpeg). I look at the tutorials and they seem very incomplete, they will say things like "let's pick a background, I'll pick this one" but it's not one that's there for you to choose and there is zero information about how that background was created. My kids would all be better than this than me, but ask them to code a prime number sieve and they'd likely be stuck!

Author: HybridZ_YT#0667
Content: why dont you just convert the image format?

Author: Anne Harrison#8994
Content: I can turn something into a bmp if that is what is needed, but I can't find any guidance on size, or how to add costumes - turn something into a complete sprite vs a single image.

Author: Anne Harrison#8994
Content: Plus I'm no genius on creating these images!

Author: Sinergy#7605
Content: @Anne Harrison with a sprite selected in the panel in the bottom right, click the costumes tab at the top, and then "choose a costume" down the bottom left, and choose upload.  then on the sprite you could have a forever loop with a "next costume" piece, and a "wait () seconds" piece

Author: Sinergy#7605
Content: imo as just a student, the scratch project is to get you thinking about how to implement code blocks and tie them together.  If you want to make something amazing, go nuts, but you don't need to.

Author: Sinergy#7605
Content: I don't know what you are currently seeing instead of the required behaviour.  I'm assuming it's always making the sound.  if so, 20 units is not very far at all.  Also, the distance it will use will be the distance between the centres of the two sprites.  One crude way around this would be to change the distance cutoff to 20 + maximal dimension of red_button + maximal dimension of current sprite.

Content: The lecture gave strong encouragement to create something more complex than the minimal requirements and to be original, so once I had an idea I wanted to implement it, but it seems like to do it I'm actually going to have to spend more time drawing than anything else. I've no interest in scratch, I'm fairly sure I understand all the concepts, some of which are beyond the first programming course I took (sensing/interrupts) 20 years ago. I can't imagine that there are many jobs other than in teaching where familiarity with scratch would be useful, so I'll come up with something for a minimal answer.

Author: MadDogDean#4560
Content:
> I had a pretty cool idea and it's frustrating that the graphics is the bit holding me up.
@Anne Harrison 
I've started CS50 2x already and haven't yet finished (a little thing called LIFE intervened...). I haven't yet done the Scratch module, not becuase I can't, but because I felt the same way you did. But in the end, it is just a stepping stone to get the ball rolling towards **THINKING **logically. Maybe you can take your idea, simplify it somewhat, and then put it together. 
If the Scratch module were an art class, a watercolor would be just as good as the Mona Lisa - at least that's my thought and take on it :)
Good luck

Author: Anne Harrison#8994
Content: In that sense Scratch is actually a pretty good introductory language to thinking logically - especially having the sprites be able to interact with each other. I'm not sure I ever did that in Java as a student.

Author: nanana#3661
Content: I'm trying to make the cat bounce up and down but it gets stuck at the top and wouldn't bounce back. The script only works if I change the condition for setting the flag to falling to "y position > 126". Does anyone understand why it is y > 126 and not y = 126?

Author: Berky_Ross#6951
Content: It's obvious lol, as long as the y changes from 126, the statement is false, so you will never get falling again, but if u set it to y > 126, it will keep asking if y is higher than 126 returning true everytime unless it's less than 126

Author: Berky_Ross#6951
Content: or 126 itself

Author: nanana#3661
Content: oh i see. thanks!

Content:
https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/372213002 Can you help me with 2 things?

1 - My second background (it's actually a sprite) blends with the first one at the start of the game unless you press the green flag twice.

2 - The animation of the centaur is awkward and that causes problems to kicking as well

Author: jfk52917#1188
Content: I took a glance at your code, specifically looking at your first point - could you explain how you trigger the second background to initiate?

Author: congergs#8362
Content: So basically, what you see as my second backdrop is an animated sprite, actually. Behind it is my real second backdrop and it's pure white. When I switch to that white backdrop, I make the castle background appear with the help of this block.

Author: jfk52917#1188
Content: I don't know how doable this is, but is it possible to make it into a backdrop?

Author: jfk52917#1188
Content: It might be a bit easier to code around if you do so

Author: jfk52917#1188
Content: I was looking at the code, and I notice that you do include "hide," so I'm a bit confused myself as to why it might appear

Author: jfk52917#1188
Content: Alternatively, I think I found a fix

Author: jfk52917#1188
Content: If you alter that piece of code you have in the photo by removing "wait until backdrop name = backdrop1"

Author: jfk52917#1188
Content: And replacing it as shown

Author: jfk52917#1188
Content: I'm not entirely sure what the issue was, but I wonder if, for some reason, the "backdrop name" variable wasn't reset when the green flag was clicked, because the issue you describe only occurred the second time I would try to initialize the game.

Author: congergs#8362
Content: Well, that's interesting: I moved the "switch backdrop to Castle 2" block somewhat higher and it appears to be working this way as well

Author: congergs#8362
Content: This is how it was before

Author: congergs#8362
Content: So my theory is that: The background was reset, but since it was the 11th block, it actually reset after the Castle_Interior/sprite was checking for the backdrop, because it was the third block after the green flag click

Author: congergs#8362
Content: But I don't know if the order is that relevant, because those things happen very instantaneously

Author: congergs#8362
Content: Thank you very much

Author: Abriella#6884
Content: Hey everyone! im new to the whole course and am currently working on my scratch assignment, i have a sprite that is set to turn everytime it reaches certain coordinates, im trying to give the illusion of a fish swimming in a bowl, and it works for a few turns before it continues to glide without turning, bounces twice then it works again. Is anyone able to help me troubleshoot?

Author: ziller#6589
Content: @Tovarish... could the sprites not all be clones with some logic to determine their individual behaviour and costumes? That way they can all share the same master code...

Author: drail159#6376
Content: @ziller has a good point, you could think of your base Sprite as a prototype and just give it whatever costumes it needs to represent the entities in your project. Then clones of that Sprite could pick whatever costumes they need in order to fulfill their role. Then they would all have the same code as the prototype. No more copy/paste. The logic to determine costume and behavior would be extra work but it sounds like that's what you're looking for.

Author: Abriella#6884
Content: It was an error in my programming, i can‚Äôt remember at the moment what was wrong because I‚Äôm in class but it was something along the lines of me choosing ‚Äòturn 90 degrees‚Äô instead of ‚Äòturn 180‚Äô and also, I separated the code for the swimming animation and the movement.

Content: Hi guys ! I've just started the CS50 and for my first Scratch project, I've read the specs and it says this. By scripts we understand story, right?

Author: Gloria#1154
Content: Hey guys ! I've just started the scratch project and in the specs it says that it needs at least "three scripts in total (not necessarily per sprite)". By scripts we understand stories right?

Author: Gloria#1154
Content: My underlying question is : what if there's only one option to your project, it being playing (if it's a game, which is my case) or losing?

Author: alexbeet#9218
Content: @Minnie Thank you! I also played a similar game as a kid; it's not completely original...

Author: alexbeet#9218
Content: @Gloria script here refers to code. For example, if you have a sprite and you can make it move around the screen, that's one script.

Author: Minnie#1629
Content: @alexbeet I loved it though!

Author: Minnie#1629
Content: @Gloria My project is a rather simple madlib and I used 6-8 scripts overall. I have 1 script for each sprite's pieces of the conversation, and then from there just added on a few items to make it more fun including some animated walking/flying at the beginning, a song loop to get the required sound clip, and a separate script for the variable collection from the user and the compilation of the answers into the madlib story. If you're doing a game I'm sure you'll not have much trouble getting at least 3 scripts, particularly because you need 2+ sprites and each sprite has their own script. Does that make sense?

Author: Scyllarus#6711
Content: The best I can think of is to create a character that starts off hidden inside an invisible box sprite, and it teleports to a random position within the bounds of that box while creating (x) clones, but I'm not sure if there's a way to generate variables to represent the x/y bounds of a sprite

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: I implemented something similar by having an invisible main object that would set local variables and then create a clone that would initialise its position from those values.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Not sure that's a great way, but worked back in Scratch2. Wish I could have spent more time on actual "programming", I've heard the new Scratch3 is more stable than the old Flash-based Scratch2.

Author: Cockashi Hatake#2062
Content: @‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ thank you, for starters, is submit50 something I need to install along with Python 3.6 and pip to submit my projects?

Author: ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢#2676
Content: @Cockashi Hatake no, you don‚Äôt need to install anything in your computer. You can go to this website instead https://ide.cs50.io/ Once you sign in using your GitHub username/password the website will take you to a web application called C9 which is a website that offers an Integrated Development Environment (IDE) similar to the one used by David Malan in the lectures.

Author: ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢#2676
Content: Once the IDE loads, you will see three panes: file explorer (left), code editor (top) and terminal (bottom). Following the instructions on each problem set you will create files, write code in the editor, and then submit the code using the command `submit50 blah/blah/blah` in the terminal

Author: ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢#2676
Content: Once submitted, you can check here ‚Üí https://submit.cs50.io/ if your code is well formatted and working as expected. If you don‚Äôt get a 100% percent then click the link of the submission to see where is the failure, fix it, submit again, and so on until you get 100% . If I remember correctly, you pass with >70% but striving for 100% is always good üôÇ

Content:
> how do you incorporate one
@rabihahaha if you look at David's examples from lecture (linked from the pset0 page), you'll find this is one:  https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/326127900/editor/   notice how it has a variable called 'counter'  (click the variables tab)

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
> https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/380318787/
> Hey guys! here's my scratch project I'm working on. I have a couple of questions:
> 1) Why doesn't Score appear on the screen?
> 2) Why if the balls touch the rocket they don't dissapear as it supossed to be?
@Yaroslav 1.  if you want it to appear, be sure to tick the box next to its name in the Variables list.  2. your 'if ball touching' block will only happen after the 10 second glide finishes. (the block before).

Author: strobelite#3015
Content: @Kiml1n Can I make a suggestion about moving the parrot? I just found this out today... instead of using the "when _____ key pressed" blocks, something like this works better

Author: strobelite#3015
Content: You might have noticed that when you first press one of the arrow keys, the character moves a bit, stops for a split second, and then continues moving. Doing it this way avoids that pause

Author: Kiml1n#5248

Author: strobelite#3015
Content: Yeah, just use if <key ___ pressed> instead. it works much better üôÇ

Author: Silverpicker#3994
Content: I'm trying to make a scratch game where different sprites enter the scene depending on player choices. Every time I create a new sprite, it automatically shows up from the start. How do I make it only enter when the main sprite reaches a certain milestone?

Author: Dragon317Slayer#0963
Content:
When green flag clicked
hide @Silverpicker

Author: Dragon317Slayer#0963
Content: There should be a block under looks called hide which hides the sprite

Author: Dragon317Slayer#0963
Content: There is also one called show I think that makes the sprite appear

Author: Silverpicker#3994
Content: Thanks!

Author: Silverpicker#3994
Content: Now that I see that, I guess my real question is more fundamental. I don't understand how the sprites interact if you are coding them separately. Let's say I want sprite #2 to disappear only if the player (whose character is sprite 1) answers a question correctly?

Author: psychodoughb0y#0892
Content: That's what events are for.  You can fire an event in one object and receive it in another.

Author: Silverpicker#3994
Content: @psychodoughb0y Thanks a ton. I'm super new to this and tried googling this before asking here. Appreciate the help and also answering me without judgement (i.e without saying, "just google it")

Author: psychodoughb0y#0892
Content: No problem.  Scratch can be a bit confusing.

Author: PhazonicRidley#1432
Content: hey quick question is there a way to get a sprite to appear after something happens, like if a condition is met

Author: PhazonicRidley#1432
Content: also are there ways to have multiple sprites doing the same thing using one code block chain and is there a way to delete a sprite when an action happens

Author: dylantheop#8853
Content: The former question yes.

Author: dylantheop#8853
Content: So for example: I think you'd have something like If this X is met broadcast Y for one sprite. Then the spirte you want to do something upon receiving the Y broadcast would when, when receive Y do X

Author: dylantheop#8853
Content: Or Z

Author: dylantheop#8853
Content: I'm not 100% as I'm still planning my project

Author: dylantheop#8853
Content: Also, your latter question, when you say delete a sprite when something happens I don't think you can do that. However, what you can do is than when something happens (X) you can make a broadcast event like the previous scenario to hide the sprite when something happens

I guess:
Repeat [if *death* (change (death) by (1))]

Content: hi guys, I'm doing the CS50b - and it says I have to use at least one condition - I'm not sure what this is - I have made a glass of watter that can catch random apples falling down. and a dragon that changes dresses and askes not to be catched when you get him. is this like a loop and condition and variable?

Content: do i see this right that a "if else" is a condition?

Content: and a variable is a " i.e. to count 10 apples to catch"?

Author: dylantheop#8853
Content: I'd say if else is a condition. As you'd be saying If this happens do this, else do this. if else is just If X is met do this, if not do this instead. It's just easier than doing two if's

Author: Oceanlight#4098
Content: @latams I think I know what your problem is.. To turn the sprite around, you need to do `set rotation style` **left-right** (so the image won't be upside down when it turns) and then do `turn` **180** `degrees` (David explains it around __46:30__ in lecture 0) - feel free to @mention or dm me if you have any other questions...

Author: Oceanlight#4098
Content: I hope this helps! *And sorry no one was able to help you out yet*üòÜ hopefully you'll really get to enjoy programming the way I do!! :))

Author: Oceanlight#4098
Content:
@Mrkela as always there are multiple ways to make the messages display one at a time when space is hit, but here‚Äôs the the best (least repetitive) way I can think of:
-  create a list (kind of like a javascript array) containing all the messages the fairy will have (click ‚Äòcreate a list‚Äô in variables)
- make a `counter` variable (or whatever u want to call it) and set it to 0
- then set up a ‚Äòwhen space clicked‚Äô event that displays __item `counter` in <message list name>__
    that‚Äôll be something like **say** (item `counter` in `messages`)
- after you displayed the message, increment `counter` by 1 so it selects the next message when space is clicked again

if this seems a bit confusing, (sry i‚Äôm probably not the best at explaining things XD) I‚Äôd encourage you to google __scratch list tutorial__ or something like that

Content: On a semi-related note, how should I create a turn based system?

Author: frostythedev#0358
Content: Of course! Anytime you have questions I'm sure others and myself will be here to help where we can, after all that's why we're all here

Author: frostythedev#0358
Content: @brodoyouevengame The way I would think about a turn based system would be to have a timer so that each turn could only go on for a certain amount of time (let's say 15s per turn before it just passes) and you could use a variable [0,1] or [true,false] to determine who's turn it is as it's only 2 persons who would be in a duel

Author: The Manly Fairy#8453
Content:
it's a card game, you have a set of cards but every 2 cards are identical
you put all the cards facing down and every turn you flip 2
if you flip 2 matching cards, you take them for yourself and get a point
if you flip 2 different cards, you flip them back to being hidden
hence you have to try to memorize where each card is and find its match

Author: SmallBones#7531
Content:
Hi guys! I have a problem and I am hoping somebody can help me.
Basically the cat needs to change costumes based on the costume of the fish that she touches. The fish falls from the sky and if the fish is normal she is supposed to switch to a happy face and if the fish contains a ‚Äúhidden‚Äù pill she is supposed to look mad.
The way the code is now the cat looks happy no matter what fish she eats. I have tried every combination I can and it will not react to the second costume of the fish. I even added a variable for the fish costumes but it didn‚Äôt do anything. I would like to avoid making a third sprite for the fish with the pill, if possible.
I am new at this and any help will be appreciated. Many thanks!

Author: Jacob#6236
Content:
Hey. I just started CS50 and I'm already banging my head into my desk over this first Scratch assignment. I want to explain the rules of the game I'm making in the beginning in such a fashion that the "host" says a line, then waits until the player presses spacebar, then says the next line, and so on, five lines total. 

Whatever I do, the moment I press spacebar, every line is triggered simultaneously, which results in only the last one being shown on the screen. How do I make it so pressing spacebar simply triggers the next line, not every line?
Thanks...

Author: wafflaffle#3902
Content:
@smokykon Maybe if you track the amount of time your arrows are clicked, you will be able to conditionally set arrows to move out of view from the canvas. 

Something like... 

create a new variable called arrowLeftTracker

`
> > if arrowLeftTracker = 3
>  > then move arrowLeft out of view
> else
> when arrowLeft is clicked
> > switch backdrop to... 
> > add 1 to arrowLeftTracker`

Author: 0xB0BAFE77#7465
Content:
@sinncrozz There's a typo on the "no" suggestion of fishing. "Hmm... You don0't want to get wet?"
Grammatically, you should use "fish" as the plural of "fish". EG "Nice you got me 10 Fishes" should be "Nice you got me 10 Fish".
The choice of yes/no doesn't respond with y or n. 
I'd suggest giving the user instructions on how to fish.
The person needs to know to click on the fish to catch them.
I tried moving my mouse over and hooking the first 5 or so fish not realizing I needed to click.

My 2 cents. Good luck, sinn.

Content:

Content: @superfistdandy People making complicated Scratch projects likely have some CS experience. But as David said in the lecture, 2/3rds of CS50 students have none. Don't be discouraged by the other projects. As long as you are able to meet the constraints of the assignment, you're doing fine.

Author: 0xB0BAFE77#7465
Content: In the example I gave, i was using the variable as the direction to move. It's not a "tap a key > move the character" setup. It's a "the character is actively moving and tapping a key changes their direction" setup.

Author: 0xB0BAFE77#7465
Content: That's what the whole spacebar thing was for. To start a loop that moves the sprite at set intervals.

Author: 0xB0BAFE77#7465
Content: Tapping the key sets the direction it's supposed to go. I can't really think of a good way of doing that without using a var.

Author: 0xB0BAFE77#7465
Content: Also, do you mean change y? "set y to" would require providing a hard coordinate to move the sprite to.

Author: Windak#9188
PortobelloPirate#1091
Content: @Windak The Wait function should be inside the IF function. Since it is outside, it gets called regardless of whether or not Scratch is touching the goblin. So when Scratch does touch the goblin, the Wait function has to resolve first, which is where that little bit of lag is showing up.

Author: Windak#9188
Content:
> @Windak The Wait function should be inside the IF function. Since it is outside, it gets called regardless of whether or not Scratch is touching the goblin. So when Scratch does touch the goblin, the Wait function has to resolve first, which is where that little bit of lag is showing up.
@PortobelloPirate oh, okay, thanks a lot! So, when it comes to the same subsets of code, all unconditional scripts work before conditional(e.g. if), right?

Author: Bunkeror#9322
Content:
OK, I give up. My brain is going to melt. 
Let's see if I can explain this well. 
I have an improvised "cinematic" where two characters have a conversation. Each character's mouth is an invisible ball sprite, so there are two sprites having a conversation. As it is... Well, a conversation... Each one must only start speaking when the other has finished. 
I thought I could so sort of a walkie-talkie thing. As Scratch doesn't have yet a "wait until broadcast" block, I made two custom blocks; "over" and "over and out", and a general "over" variable.

Author: Bunkeror#9322
Content: This one's the custom "over"

Author: Bunkeror#9322
Content: And the selected, unaligned one is the "over and out"

Author: Bunkeror#9322
Content: I added each one in both talking sprites, of course

Author: Bunkeror#9322
Content: The algorith is: when the previous dialogue ends, the "over" variable is set to 2. When the next one starts, the sprite that speaks first can do so right away. The other one finds an "over" block. As the variable is 2, it sets it to zero and waits for it to be 1. Meanwhile, the other one finds its own "over" block. As the variable is now zero, it sets it to one and after a delay, it waits for it to be one again. Why? Because during that delay, the other one has passed the "wait until one" phase and has set the variable to zero and continued speaking. Then it finds its own over, sets it to one, the other one sets it to zero and speaks... And so on. When "over and out" is called, it sets the variable to 2 and just lets the last waiting "over" to finish without doing anything.

Author: Bunkeror#9322
Content: Now, the problem is... It doesn't work only when it's the second ball the one which speaks first. I don't know why, because the custom block is the same in both sprites. The variable changes quickly from 2 to 1 to 0 (which... I mean, the code does what I tell it to do, be it wrong or right, but I don't think I have told it to do that) and then both start speaking at once, ignoring the stops in each over block.

Author: Bunkeror#9322
Content: I recall that asking for ideas or a direct solution is not permitted, so... Does any of you understand this jigsaw I created, and can figure out what did I do wrong? Thanks in advance!

Author: Bunkeror#9322
Content: The added 0.5 s stops are just for debugging

Author: Bunkeror#9322
Content: OK, I gave up and fixed it using a workaround. Thanks anyways, I'll leave this text wall here for the record

Author: Bunkeror#9322
Content: Definitely, fixed. Phew

Author: softballvr4511#2390
Content:
Your project must have at least two sprites, at least one of which must resemble something other than a cat.
Your project must have at least three scripts total (i.e., not necessarily three per sprite).
Your project must use at least one condition, one loop, and one variable.
Your project must use at least one sound.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
> Also, I'm noticing that blocks are created per each sprite, is there a way to do a global block so I don't have to recreate a block for each sprite?
@plazma no globals, but if you have the same script that you want to execute for another block, you can drag it into your 'backpack' at the bottom, and then choose the other sprite, and drag it up for that one.

Author: Bunkeror#9322
Content: OK, so... My project has a pause feature, where a variable is set to 1, and every loop that checks for that variable (pretty much all affected) waits until it becomes zero again. It works, but I have a level where there's a series of events that happen during a level. And I find that the wait X seconds blocks just ignore my pause feature; the thing won't actually trigger until I unpause, but the timer will continue running. Do you think it's worth it to put a repeat X times (wait Y seconds -> wait until Pause=0) to replace a Wait X*Y seconds block? Has any of you tested something similar before?

Author: mikelyons#8548
Content:
Hi there,

I'm currently using Scratch and I'm having some difficultly with the application. I want to create a basketball game where the basketball (sprite) goes into the hope. The back drop is a basketball court and I want the basketball to go into the hoop. Is this possible? Or do I have to create my own hoop for this to work? Your help would be greatly appreciated. Thanks.

Author: Bunkeror#9322
Content: @mikelyons There is no way to tell your ball "go into the hoop", because Scratch doesn't actually know that's a hoop (or that it's a ball). You have to tell the ball "go to these coordinates" (I'd recommend hover rather than go to), and those coordinates may be a point of the trajectory or where the hoop is located in the Scratch window. Did I explain it well?

Author: mikelyons#8548
Content: Yes you did.  Thanks.

Author: moonsprouts#4942
Content: Can someone help me understand the broadcast and when I receive <insert message>? How do you define what the message is?

Author: Scholar_NZ#5518
Content:
Okay, so Broadcast is how I've done my entire game Taco Bear so far.
https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/392022977/editor/

Think of a broadcast as a guy with a megaphone saying something so that the whole game can hear it.

The event "Receive <message>" then triggers when the other parts of the game hear it.

To create a message, click on the drop-down then select "New Message". This will then appear in the drop down list in future when you select a Broadcast or a "when I recieve" event

Author: Scholar_NZ#5518
Content: E.g - someone clicks on the green flag in the start of my game, which prompts everyone that it's time to go to the intro ("Intro time!" is broadcast) This causes all the sprites that I don't want anymore to "Hide", as they've all got that event

Author: Scholar_NZ#5518
Content: Hooopefully this helps - I'm still getting to grips with Scratch as it's early days for me.

Author: moonsprouts#4942
Content: So basically it's a way to link sprites together so they can be affected by each other?

Author: Scholar_NZ#5518
Content: That's how I'm treating it, yeah üôÇ

Author: moonsprouts#4942
Content: Do I have to define what happens when I broadcast something like I have to define a block?

Author: Scholar_NZ#5518
Content: Yeah, so you'll have a broadcast, then every sprite that you want to have affected by it needs to have a "when I recieve" event to tell it what to do

Author: Scholar_NZ#5518
Content: There isn't a way to group sprites that I've found

Author: moonsprouts#4942
Content: Ok I think I understand! I just need to put it into practice to really get my head around it. Thank you!!!!

Author: Scholar_NZ#5518
Content: All good - we're all tryna get by with this stuff haha

Content:
> is it necessary to do the hello, world part
@yesnt 
You get out what you put in, if you're familiar with C and computer programming it'll only take you a minute to do that.

If you're familiar with coding but not C, it might take you a little longer (like it did me a few days ago) whilst you get to grips with the new syntax

If you're not familiar with coding at all I mean, it's not necessary, but you only get out what you put in

Author: Ali Rizwan#4297
Content:
Hi guys I have a question regarding scratch
Suppose youre creating a game where program emits different audios based on the distance of the sprite to the cursor
What subrotine would allow us to do that?

Author: Scholar_NZ#5518
Content:
Well, you'd want either a variable or something else that constantly reads the cursor's position, and then you'd want another with the position of the sprite.
You could then calculate the distance between them with another variable, lets say call it Cursor Distance (one for x and y each) You could use a if routine to go "If cursor distance x = blah && cursor distance y == blahblah".

Author: Scholar_NZ#5518
Content: Hopefully that makes sense

Author: Kimicn#8688
Content: Hey guys I just started the course. Very new to CS. In scratch,  what counts as a script? a whole block of commands to a sprite?

Author: bluepinguinilauti#6506
Content: ^ yea same

Author: Savaris#8229
Content: @Kimicn  *A script is defined within the Scratch program as one or a set of blocks that begins with a Hat Block. Even a single block can qualify. However, scripts are usually referred to as sets of blocks that consist of at least two blocks.*

Author: Kimicn#8688
Content: @Savaris  So a script is one group of blocks? so I would need to have 3 sprites and three different blocks of script for each one? To meet criteria of problem 0?

Author: Savaris#8229
Content: @Kimicn  Most programmers consider a script as a few lines of code (few puzzle pieces in scratch). As for how many scripts per sprite -> *Your project must have at least three scripts total (i.e., not necessarily three per sprite).*

Author: Kimicn#8688
Content: @Savaris  Okay thanks! I'm very new at this and hope i am doing this to the criteria lol.

Author: Savaris#8229
Content: Don't worry, i am new to this as well. Currently trying to create a minigame myself with scratch üòÅ

Author: CelParadise#9113
Content: if you hide the sprite: use an if condition inside the sprite tab, insert "touching" (under "sensing") and assign it to the sprite. Into the if bracket you insert "hide" and "change VARIABLE by 1". The if condition needs to be in a forever loop triggered by an event (like starting the program or pressing space)
